Award.AwardTitle: Micro-processes Driven by Shear Alfv√©n Waves Generating Parallel Potential Drop in the Auroral Plasma
Award.AbstractNarration:
Alfven waves are thought to play a significant role in the auroral particle acceleration process, but the plasma processes, which convert the Alfven wave energy into the electrostatic energy in a parallel potential drop (PPD), are still not fully understood. This project will continue a line of research in this topic that has used a two-fluid magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model. In this two-fluid model the electric field parallel to the magnetic field lines is calculated from the electron momentum equation. The electron momentum equation includes linear and nonlinear inertial terms as well as an anomalous collision term. The anomalous collision term is an heuristic model of the electrostatic ion cyclotron (EIC) instability. The two-fluid model has been successful on a number of fronts, but these types of models are know to miss kinetic and microphysical processes such as (i) multi-streaming of charged particles and resulting micro-instabilities, (ii) plasma heating resulting in plasma evacuation and cavity formation, (iii) formation of micro-scale PPD like a double layer (DL) and (iv) effects of mirror force.

The main thrust of this project will be to study the meso-scale propagation of shear Alfven waves (SAWs) using kinetic simulations that include the appropriate microphysics in a self-consistent way. The simulations will be done with a 2.5-dimensional particle-in-cell code. The primary focuses of attention for the project will be (i) the wave modes responsible for the anomalous resistivity, (ii) anomalous plasma heating resulting in cavity creation, (iii) cavity creation by nonlinear ponderomotive force, and (iv) double layer formation localizing E-parallel in cavities as seen in data from the FAST and Polar satellites. The research will determine the relative importance of double layers, anomalous resistivity, and mirror force in establishing the PPD in a propagating SAW, and will augment MHD and two-fluid MHD modeling efforts by providing rigorously determined expressions for the anomalous resistivity. The project will include research experience and support for a graduate student and undergraduate students. The parallelized kinetic code is used as a teaching tool for teaching parallel computing courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We richly contributed to the topic of double layer formations in plasmas. Realizing that the work on current free double layers have been done in various contexts in plasma physics and space physics without realizing the commonalities, we researched and wrote an exhaustive review article published in Physics of Plasma. In this review we synthesized a large body of knowledge found from laboratory experiments, theory, simulations and modeling. In the context of the auroral plasma physics we found that the  low altitude double layers below the auroral cavities are nearly the current free double layers supported by the upward expanding hot population of backscattered and secondary electrons in the midst of the ionospheric cold plasma. We further suggested that similar double layers can contribute to the origin of solar wind in the upper solar chromosphere, where magnetic reconnection energizes a small fraction of the cold chromospheric electrons. Simulating very long two dimensional plasmas, we studied the formation of electron holes, their motion over thousands of Debye lengths and how they dissipate giving their energy to the background plasma. We discovered formation of weak double layers in the transversely narrow structures of inertial Alfven waves.

 

     Our work on double layers extended to developing a theoretical frame work for explaining double layer formation in plasmas expanding in diverging/converging magnetic field lines.  For these studies we developed a two-dimensional particle-in-cell code including the diverging/converging magnetic fields.

 

     In search of generation of dispersive Alfven waves by magnetic reconnection events, we proposed that when reconnection occurs electromagnetic waves are launched; the typical wave modes are the slow MHD, whistler and dispersive shear Alfven waves (kinetic and inertial Alfven wave modes). A direct experimental evidence of this has come from the laboratory experiments at MIT; we interpreted the explosive spontaneous reconnection events over a few microseconds as whistler wave events. Observational evidence of our idea that the group velocity cones of kinetic Alfven waves determine the exhaust cone angle in the reconnection structures has been reported from Cluster observation. We have performed further research on the temporal and spatial dispersive properties of kinetic Alfven waves that determine the reconnection exhaust structure, but not published yet. 
 
      We investigated the propagation of inertial Alfven waves (IAWs) demonstrating that the narrow structures of IAWs act like antennas as they radiate electrostatic ion cyclotron waves (EICW) and electrostatic whistler waves above the lower hybrid frequency. The latter waves originate from the leading head of the propagating IAWS and appear as cat whiskers. The whistler waves are generated by electron beams accelerated by the parallel electric fields in the leading edge. The parallel fields are highly dynamic; the fields dynamically evolve into weak double layers and electron holes.
